prompt_data.system_prompt: You are an expert at classifying comments as othering or not. Classify as 'Othering' only if the statement explicitly or implicitly positions a group of people (or an individual as representative of a group) as fundamentally different, inferior, or outside belonging. Do not classify personal insults or disagreements as Othering unless they clearly invoke group identity. Answer in JSON format only with 'Othering' or 'None' for 'label' and a short sentence explaining your decision process in 'reasoning' and identify the target group in 'target'. Context keywords should help you understand the meaning of the text, but do not assume any additional information.
prompt_data.question: Is this statement othering or not? Only classify it as 'Othering' if you are above 90% certain.

demos.text: Those immigrants don't want to fit in; they'll never be like us.

answer.label: Othering
answer.reasoning: Creates a boundary, casts the group as unwilling outsiders, reinforces exclusion

demos.text: Unlike us, women are too emotional to make rational decisions.

answer.label: Othering
answer.reasoning: Essentializes and negatively stereotypes women as inherently deficient.

demos.text: People from that neighborhood are lazy and don't care about hard work.

answer.label: Othering
answer.reasoning: Attributes a negative trait to an entire group, erasing individuality

demos.text: She's not one of us, but at least she tries.

answer.label: Othering
answer.reasoning: Positions someone as an outsider while granting conditional tolerance.

demos.text: They just don't value freedom the way we do.

answer.label: Othering
answer.reasoning: Establishes an in-group (“we” as true holders of freedom) and frames “them” as lacking.

demos.text: You're such an idiot, nobody takes you seriously.

answer.label: None
answer.reasoning: Insults an individual but does not invoke a group identity or boundary.

4.text: Bruh, I don't even like g-dragon but his comment is accurate af in describing how you'd come off as some socially awkward neckbeard if you talked like that to a girl.

3.text: “Hi Kpop girl can I send you a pic of g-dragon” “Woohoo I can’t wait! Please send it right away!” “Here you go” *sends a pic of g-dragon with no make up* “Ugh! No you spoilt my day! Hehe!”

annotation.reasoning: The conversation is about a K-pop fan's excitement to receive and share pictures of G-Dragon. There's no indication of creating an 'us versus them' scenario or positioning a group as inferior.

21.text: The % of Muslims is similar in both countries. The only *significant* difference is that Singapore has a much higher % of Christians and Catholics. So just to clarify - people from those two groups are bigots that preventing social progress. Let's call a spade a spade. >might not be worth removing a law that isn't enforced anyway. So this law is simultaneously meaningless while also being of such importance to cause harm? You can't really have it both ways.

annotation.label: Othering
annotation.reasoning: Creates a boundary by framing Christians and Catholics as bigots preventing social progress, casting them as unwilling outsiders.

22.text: > The % of Muslims is similar in both countries. The only significant difference is that Singapore has a much higher % of Christians and Catholics. So just to clarify - people from those two groups are bigots that preventing social progress. Let's call a spade a spade. Using your reasoning, the higher % of Christians and Catholics are also responsible for reducing the prevalence of sex crimes. If you use that line of thinking it cuts both ways.

annotation.label: Othering
annotation.reasoning: Creates a boundary between people of different religious affiliations and positions Christians and Catholics as bigots preventing social progress.

23.text: >Using your reasoning, the higher % of Christians and Catholics are also responsible for reducing the prevalence of sex crimes. If you use that line of thinking it cuts both ways. Do Christians and Catholics speak out against sex crimes more than any other group in Singapore? Meanwhile, we know for a fact that those two religions are vehemently opposed to homosexuality. Please just look at things like the AWARE saga, NLB book fiasco or the Wear White campaign. So yeah, your argument makes no sense, because there's correlation for one issue while none for the other.

annotation.label: Othering
annotation.reasoning: Creates a boundary between Christians/Catholics and others by implying they are uniquely responsible for reducing sex crimes and uniquely opposed to homosexuality.

24.text: Your thinking is too simplistic. Just because people don't vehemently speak out against homosexuality does not mean that they support LGBT. The method by which you "determined" correlation is laughably dumb. Saudi Arabia has no Catholics and Christians, why don't they have gay marriage as well? But its okay. You can continue labouring under the delusion that all that stands in the way of gay marriage are Christians and Catholics.

annotation.label: Othering
annotation.reasoning: Creates an in-group of presumably enlightened individuals and positions Christians and Catholics as unenlightened outsiders due to their perceived stance on gay marriage.

25.text: You are backtracking. Someone posted a bunch of reasons why Singapore as a whole may be opposed to LGBT outside of religion and your response was this: > "The only significant difference is that Singapore (as compared to India) has a much higher % of Christians and Catholics. So just to clarify - people from those two groups are bigots that preventing social progress. Let's call a spade a spade." Go ahead and try to shift the goal posts into "whether Christians and Catholics are opposed to LGBT". I'm done here.

annotation.label: Othering
annotation.reasoning: Creates a boundary by implying Christians and Catholics are uniquely opposed to LGBT individuals, portraying them as obstacles to social progress.

26.text: Ceddya's point is that there is a much higher % of Christians in Singapore, while the % of Muslims in Singapore and India are similar. Saudi Arabia on the other hand is practically the center of Islam, so it's not an apples-to-apples comparison.

annotation.label: None
annotation.reasoning: The statement makes a factual comparison between religious demographics in different regions without positioning any group as fundamentally different or inferior.

I won't be continuing this discussion any further, but thanks for taking a civil tone.

annotation.label: None

36.text: I like to see this as a two-perspective issue: perception vs treatment. Women are *perceived* to be weaker, therefore they are *treated* better by the law. Men are *perceived* to be stronger, therefore the law *treats* them worse. So things like NS are men-only because women are perceived as too weak to handle it. Depending on how you look at it, you can see this as discrimination against either gender.

annotation.label: Othering
annotation.reasoning: Implies that women are inherently weaker and need special treatment under the law, creating an unequal boundary between genders.

37.text: >So things like NS are men-only because women are perceived as too weak to handle it. Hardly true. Women are allowed to serve in the army if they wish to.

39.text: I'm still not seeing any actual problem. What's the actual harm to women that's caused by this mindset? Are they being denied any opportunities? What actual problem does this cause to women? All I can see are benefits to this and no disadvantages.

41.text: I don't. I'm just trying to explain the thought process. Whether it fits the day-to-day "feel" for what definition means is another issue.
